awd_titl_txt: Quantitative Elucidation of the Role of Natural Organic Matter Fractions and Models on the Redox Reactivity of Iron Oxide Minerals
awd_abstract_narration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division funds Professors Lee Penn and Bill Arnold of the University of Minnesota for this project. They study pollutant degradation reactions that occur on iron oxide mineral particles in the presence and absence of natural organic matter (NOM).  NOM can be found in most natural waters. It is formed from the decomposition of plant material and produced by algae and other microorganisms. NOM is a complex mixture of molecules, with some inhibiting and others facilitating reactions that occur at the liquid-mineral interface.  This means that NOM impacts the persistence of pollutant molecules in the environment. The types of NOM molecules in the environment change when exposed to mineral surfaces. The NOM remaining in the water will evolve with exposure to the minerals in environmental systems, a process called fractionation. Little is known about how different fractions of NOM impact the reactivity of iron oxide mineral surfaces. Answering this question will bridge major gaps between laboratory and field studies.   Results from the collaboration between the investigators will deepen fundamental understanding of the nature and evolution of NOM in environmental systems and the impact of NOM on reactions involving common organic contaminants. The broader impacts of this work include potential societal benefits caused by improved understanding of the chemical behavior of mineral surfaces in environmental systems. The major educational component focuses on high school students through a collaboration with a science teacher from a Minnesota Public School. Students receive instruction and hands on experience in using quantitative camera phone colorimetry with simulated water treatment using straw columns filled with various materials, including mineral coated sands and carbon produced from biomass.

A major project focus is the progressive fractionation of NOM as a function of exposure to mineral surfaces.  NOM fractionation is accomplished by a combination of chemical and physical methods. The amount of NOM used in a reactor is normalized to the total organic carbon. The rate of pollutant degradation is studied in the presence of minerals and different amounts and fractions of NOM.   In addition, mineral particles are characterized using advanced materials characterization methods before, during, and after reactions to identify where on the particles the reaction occurs and how the NOM fractions affect the reaction location. Results enable elucidation of the nature of NOM fractions that most strongly (and weakly) impact reactivity and thus the persistence of pollutants.  The team uses NOM standards obtained from the International Humic Substances Society (IHSS) and NOM samples collected from the environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Iron oxide mineral nanoparticles and organic matter (OM) are ubiquitous in the environment.  Iron oxide minerals play important roles in the geochemical cycling of the elements and other chemical species and participate in reactions that can result in the degradation of toxic pollutants like nitroaromatics.  The behavior of iron oxide mineral nanoparticles changes dramatically when OM is present, and the impact of the NOM depends on its chemical properties.  Thus, the dynamics of OM and iron oxides are closely linked in the environment. OM is formed from the decomposition of terrestrial plant material and also produced by algae and other microorganisms. 

In this work, the team engaged in four activities to address how OM impacts the chemical reactivity of iron oxide nanoparticles.  First, they successfully produced iron oxide nanoparticles with controlled phase (e.g., akageneite, goethite, hematite)  and chemical composition (e.g., aluminum substitution).  This facilitated quantification of chemical reactivity on specific mineral nanoparticles in later experiments.  Second, the kinetics of phase transformations in aqueous solutions containing varying concentrations of Fe(II) were quantified.  This was important to understanding how the mineralogy of a suspension containing iron oxides evolves over time when Fe(II) was present.  Third, the kinetics of reductive degradation of 4-chloronitrobenzene (4ClNB) by Fe(II) in the presence of a variety of the synthetic iron oxide minerals were quantified in both batch and flow-through columns.  These data provided the dataset against which experiments incorporating OM were compared.  Finally, we obtained substantial results related to the core theme of examining how OM impacts redox reactivity as a function of several variables. Essential findings include the observation that when OM adsorbs onto mineral nanoparticles, the NOM on the mineral surfaces is very different than the OM that remained in the aqueous phase; the observation that overgrowth of a secondary phase on the most reactive mineral nanoparticle surfaces resulted in reactivity dominated by the secondary phase; and the observation that solid-state changes in the iron oxide mineral nanoparticles was consistent between batch and flow-through reactors.  

 

Intellectual Merit:  Results have improved our fundamental understanding of how the reactivity of iron oxide surfaces is impacted by the presence of organic matter. This is an important step in elucidating the role of abiotic attenuation of contaminants in natural and engineered systems. The project team quantitatively linked solid-state (i.e., mineralogical) changes and changes with observed contaminant degradation kinetics as a function of OM characteristics. Methods were highly quantitative, and results enabled the generation of a database reflecting variability from the perspective of reactivity, variability in native mineralogy, and OM concentration and characteristics. Results represent a leap forward in fundamental understanding of degradation processes in environmental systems and are expected to fundamentally improve the prediction of pollutant fate in natural and engineered systems and impact the design and implementation of remediation systems.

Broader Impacts:  The broader impacts of this work include potential societal benefits via improved understanding of pollutant degradation reactions to facilitate cleanup of contaminated surface and ground waters.  In addition, the education of severeal Ph.D. students and numerous undergraduate students in both the Department of Chemistry and the Department of Civil, Environmental, and Geo- Engineering was fostered by this work. All students were trained to use advanced instrumentation and to link analytical chemistry results with results from solid-state characterization. Results from the research has also been used to provide classroom-based problems for undergraduate and graduate courses including General Chemistry, Environmental Water Chemistry, and Environmental Organic Chemistry. Lastly, results have been and continue to be broadly disseminated in high-quality peer-reviewed journals and at regional and national conferences. Students at all levels have participated in authoring manuscripts for publication and presentation of results at national and local conferences.

 

Image shown:  Transmission electron microscopy images of hematite (alpha-Fe2O3) nanoparticles, with 5 mol % Al substitution, before (left) and after (right) reaction with 100 ?M 4-chloronitrobenzene in an aqueous batch reactor also containing 1 mM Fe(II).  The acicular ?spikes? on the post-reaction particles are goethite (alpha-FeOOH), and compositional analysis of similar samples demonstrate that the newly formed goethite contains no aluminum and the quantitative kinetics results demonstrate that the subsequent reactivity is more similar to a batch reactor prepared with only goethite as compared to a batch reactor prepared with fresh hematite nanoparticles.
